Title:
Genetic and physiological diversity within the industrial
relevant, thermophilic genera Myceliophthora and Corynascus
Keywords:
Myceliophthora, M. heterothallica, M. thermophila,
thermophilic fungi, Corynascus
Abstract:
Species of the anamorph genus Myceliophthora and its
teleomorph Corynascus have attracted increasing interest due to their
potential to produce enzymes with a thermostable characteristic. This
study re-assessed the phylogenetic relationships of 49 isolates of nine
different species belonging to Myceliophthora and Corynascus. One
species, M. vellerea, was shown not to belong to the genus
Myceliophthora and should be placed in the genus Ctenomyces. The other
species belonged phylogenetically to two clusters: mesophilic fungi with
the type species M. lutea and C. sepedonium, and thermophilic fungi with
M. thermophila, M. hinnulea and C. thermophilus. The phylogenetic data
provides no clear separation of the two genera Corynascus and
Myceliophthora. To prevent confusion in the interpretation of future
studies, we propose to rename all Corynascus species within this taxon
to the more frequently used name Myceliophthora. Furthermore, this study
identified two groups within the isolates listed as M. thermophila and
assigned five isolates to M. heterothallica based on phylogeny, mating
behavior and physiological differences. This study provides new insights
into the genetic and physiological differences within the genus
Myceliophthora and will therefore be essential for the interpretation of
future genomic and physiological studies of these species.
